abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and institutional development
            impacts are high. Several lessons are drawn from the
            project. The level of responsibility granted to staff of
            participating institutions, was conducive in turn to the
            delegation of authority demonstrated in project management
            during implementation. Both aspects proved instrumental no
            only in securing project success, but in building ownership,
            and capacity. The relatively low cost of preparation, and
            the absence of processing requirements at the time, were
            offset by the support of quality supervision, enhanced by
            staff continuity, consistently including a mix of relevant
            Bank technical, and administrative expertise, who
            contributed to improved relations with the country. However,
            public resistance, and negative support to the project,
            could have been minimized, had a public communications
            strategy been professionally designed, early on in the
            project cycle, to build the necessary support among key
            stakeholders. Likewise, an early participatory approach
            should have been pursued to undertake a socioeconomic
            assessment of reserve resources, and thus develop community
            based strategies, to strengthen sustainable means for
            resource conservation. Most importantly, performance
            indicators should be available, to form the baseline for
            assessments of ecosystems, socioeconomic aspects, and
            factors affecting the use of natural resources.
